pullRequest.body:
Breaking changes:

- remove `Field.sepDegree` since it is not quite correct for infinite case; will be added in later PR (see #8696)

New definitions (non-exhaustive):

- `Polynomial.natSepDegree`: the separable degree of a polynomial is a natural number, defined to be the number of distinct roots of it over its splitting field.

New results (non-exhaustive):

- `Polynomial.natSepDegree_le_natDegree`: the separable degree of a polynomial is smaller than its degree.
- `Polynomial.natSepDegree_eq_natDegree_iff`: the separable degree of a non-zero polynomial is equal to its degree if and only if it is separable.
- `Polynomial.natSepDegree_dvd_natDegree_of_irreducible`: the separable degree of an irreducible polynomial divides its degree.
- `Field.finSepDegree_adjoin_simple_eq_natSepDegree`: the (finite) separable degree of `FâŸ®Î±âŸ¯ / F` is equal to the separable degree of the minimal polynomial of `Î±` over `F`.
- `Field.finSepDegree_dvd_finrank`: the separable degree of any field extension `E / F` divides the degree of `E / F`.
- `Field.finSepDegree_le_finrank`: the separable degree of a finite extension `E / F` is smaller than the degree of `E / F`.
- `Field.finSepDegree_eq_finrank_iff`: if `E / F` is a finite extension, then its separable degree is equal to its degree if and only if it is a separable extension.

---

nodes.body: Is it possible to split the PR? It is currently rather big...
I'm happy with the content, just haven't checked whether some proofs' lengths are justified :)

> Is it possible to split the PR? It is currently rather big...

This PR is already split from #8696. It's possible to further split this into two PRs, one is solely for separable degree of polynomials, another one is the application of these to separable degree of fields. But IMHO this makes PRs too fragmented.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8860~~

From a brief skim up to Line 532:
okay I've now skimmed through the whole PR. Fantastic work! Next time I'll be trying to golf some proofs ...

Can you please check the impliciteness of the variables? I've commented some of them, but I have the impression there are several others. Feel free to make a variable explicit even if its type can be inferred if you have a reason to do so, but the opposite should be avoided in my opinion.
Thanks, I think this is my final review on this PR!
Just a few more nits I missed ...

When you say "behaves badly" I think you originally mean that the cardinality #(Emb F E) doesn't behave as expected when E/F is infinite, not `Emb F E` itself. But even for the cardinality, I wouldn't say it behaves badly, because it still behaves quite regularly (equal to 2^deg (sep closure), I believe); it's just the typical behavior of automorphism groups of infinite objects.
You're right, I rephrased it a little bit. ~~But I didn't mention 2^deg (sep closure) thing.~~
I think this subsumes `finSepDegree_top`?

Oh, you're right.

[EDIT] But it breaks `rw [â† finSepDegree_top]` ðŸ˜…
I guess you just need to make `E` explicit?
Sure. Fixed.
Can you just name it `sepDegree`? A polynomial can't have infinitely many roots ...

I mimic the `degree` vs. `natDegree`, so I think that `sepDegree 0` is negative infinity. But I don't want to introduce that notation, so I named it `natSepDegree` which means that it's similar to `natDegree` but not `degree`.
Okay I see the rationale.
You can use `C_0` `C_1` combined with `natSepDegree_C`
You can prove `natSepDegree_C` with this and `natDegree_C`


I think this could go into Irreducible namespace. Polynomial.Monic namespace would be the second choice. Same for the next lemma.
It's probably unnecessary to carry the IsIntegral conditions around after #8862?

Perhaps. Later I'll go through the whole file to see how many of `IsIntegral` can be removed.

PS: We have a lot of `IsIntegral F s âˆ§ Splits (algebraMap F K) (minpoly F s)` in this file as well as previous files. I think the first condition `IsIntegral F s` can be removed, since if it's not integral, then the minimal polynomial is zero, which never splits. Do you think we also should modify those previous files?

Unfortunately, the zero polynomial always splits ([Polynomial.splits_zero](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Polynomial/Splits.html#Polynomial.splits_zero)) by definition. I don't know why people special cased 0 in the first place, maybe it's related to that Polynomial.roots 0 = 0 (this has to be special cased as a multiset can't be infinite). If you want, you may try to remove the special case and see what happens. (I've also thought about using [Polynomial.splits_of_exists_multiset](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Polynomial/Splits.html#Polynomial.splits_of_exists_multiset) as the official definition, because it generalizes to CommRings.)

> Unfortunately, the zero polynomial always splits

Oh OK ðŸ˜… I made a mistake then.

I propose the following code, extracting from #8862:
```lean
theorem Polynomial.Separable.isIntegral {A B : Type*} [CommRing A] [Ring B] [Algebra A B]
    {x : B} (h : (minpoly A x).Separable) : IsIntegral A x := by
  cases subsingleton_or_nontrivial A
  Â· haveI := Module.subsingleton A B
    exact âŸ¨1, monic_one, Subsingleton.elim _ _âŸ©
  Â· exact of_not_not fun h' â†¦ not_separable_zero (minpoly.eq_zero h' â–¸ h)
```

Then I can write:
```lean
example {A B : Type*} [CommRing A] [Ring B] [Algebra A B]
    {x : B} (h : (minpoly A x).Separable) : True := by
  have := h.isIntegral
  sorry
```

What do you think?
Submitted this to #9134.
Looks great and I'm glad it's already taken care of!

I think the reason is the same as the `monic_expand_iff`: this change makes `rw [leadingCoeff_expand hp]` becomes `rw [leadingCoeff_expand _ hp]`.
Well, you can switch the order of `hp` and `f` and your `rw` will work, but if you prefer we can keep `f` implicit.

> Well, you can switch the order of `hp` and `f` and your `rw` will work, but if you prefer we can keep `f` implicit.

IMHO I'd like to keep `f` implicit; the existing results has the order `f` then `hp`, so maybe it's a little bit awkward for the newly added results with parameter order changed.

```suggestion
theorem monic_expand_iff {p : â„•} (f : R[X]) (hp : 0 < p) : (expand R p f).Monic â†” f.Monic := by
```

I'm not sure about this, since this makes `rw [monic_expand_iff hp]` becomes `rw [monic_expand_iff _ hp]`, and breaks the following `alias ... = monic_expand_iff` (the original `Monic.expand` has `f` implicit).

Yeah I think we it's conventional to make variables implicit in rewrite (Eq or Iff) lemmas if they appear in both sides. (Here's some [recent discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Poll.20.3A.20Vscode.20loogle.20interface.20feedback/near/407461189).)

see https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8117#discussion_r1381535021 :

> > Regarding
> > > Mathematically, it should be the algebraic closure of F, but in order to make the type compatible with Module.rank F E, we use the algebraic closure of E.
> > 
> > 
> > I don't quite understand the difficulty of working with `AlgebraicClosure F`. I think it would make the inductive step to show multiplicativity of separable degree slightly easier.
> 
> Because the type of `Cardinal.mk (E â†’â‚[F] (AlgebraicClosure F))` is `Cardinal.{max u v}`, while the type of `Cardinal.mk (E â†’â‚[F] (AlgebraicClosure E))` is `Cardinal.{v}`, which is the same as `Module.rank F E`. This allows us to write `sepDegree F E = Module.rank F E` without mentioning `Cardinal.lift`.

Oh but that was a historical remark, since now `sepDegree` gets a new definition.

```suggestion
/-- The separable degree `Polynomial.natSepDegree` of a polynomial is a natural number,
defined to be the number of distinct roots of it over its splitting field.
This is similar to `Polynomial.natDegree` but not to `Polynomial.degree`, namely, the separable
degree of `0` is `0`, not negative infinity. -/
```

```suggestion
theorem natSepDegree_C (x : F) : (C x).natSepDegree = 0 := natSepDegree_eq_zero _ (natDegree_C _)
```

I think you can construct `rootsExpandPowEquivRoots` in a similar way to `rootsExpandEquivRoots` and it won't be much more work ... or you can also compose `rootsExpandPowEquivRoots` with `Equiv.Set.ofEq` to obtain `rootsExpandEquivRoots`.

```suggestion
  ((frobeniusEquiv R p).image _).trans <| Equiv.Set.ofEq <| show _ '' (setOf _) = setOf _ by
    ext r; obtain âŸ¨r, rflâŸ© := surjective_frobenius R p r
```

The API around `contraction` seems under-developed, e.g. there's no `isSeparableContraction_contraction` which is just `choose_spec`. You wouldn't need the rewrite if you add that lemma.

> The API around `contraction` seems under-developed, e.g. there's no `isSeparableContraction_contraction` which is just `choose_spec`. You wouldn't need the rewrite if you add that lemma.

Let me check later.

> The API around `contraction` seems under-developed, e.g. there's no `isSeparableContraction_contraction` which is just `choose_spec`. You wouldn't need the rewrite if you add that lemma.

Sorry, but I don't quite get what you mean. All I can think of is to extract one of the `rw` to `IsSeparableContraction.natSepDegree_eq`, and I only need one `rw` in each of the result. Is it OK?

[EDIT] Oh I got it. Do you mean this?
```lean
theorem HasSeparableContraction.isSeparableContraction {F : Type*} [CommSemiring F]
    {q : â„•} {f : Polynomial F} (h : f.HasSeparableContraction q) :
    IsSeparableContraction q f h.contraction := Classical.choose_spec h
```

[EDIT2] But it does not work:
```lean
variable {f} in
/-- If a polynomial has separable contraction, then its separable degree is equal to the degree of
the given separable contraction. -/
theorem HasSeparableContraction.natSepDegree_eq
    {q : â„•} [ExpChar F q] (hf : f.HasSeparableContraction q) :
    f.natSepDegree = hf.degree := by
  obtain âŸ¨h1, m, h2âŸ© := hf.isSeparableContraction
  rw [degree, â† h2, natSepDegree_expand]
  exact natSepDegree_eq_natDegree_of_separable _ h1
```
The `rw [â† h2]` does not work, it complains about `motive is not type correct`

[EDIT3] Nevermind, split it into two theorem works.

You can also do
```
  conv_lhs => rw [â† h2, natSepDegree_expand_eq_natSepDegree]
  exact natSepDegree_eq_natDegree_of_separable _ h1
```
to avoid the `f` inside `hf` in the RHS being rewritten, causing a motive not type correct error.
How about rename `Polynomial.Irreducible.hasSeparableContraction` to `_root_.Irreducible.hasSeparableContraction` to enable dot notation?
I think it's reasonable. Let me check later.

Mathlib/RingTheory/Polynomial/SeparableDegree.lean, L113:
```lean
#align irreducible.has_separable_contraction Polynomial.Irreducible.hasSeparableContraction
```
I suspect that it was in the global namespace before at some time? Can the history be checked?

Yes it was. [irreducible.has_separable_contraction](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/field_theory/separable_degree.html#irreducible.has_separable_contraction). It's changed [during the port](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/4287/files#diff-7547c0e47112228517421debb0e1485c210d28ab2e150495d8c140f3f08e31a4R110-R116) for unknown reason, maybe inadvertently. (Does @apurvnakade remember?)
Looking at the commit history it looks like mathport did not preserve the `_root_` anywhere!

Thanks! Indeed it's a mathport problem that [has been reported](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/mathport.20_root_/near/312413814), but a fix was never implemented.

```suggestion
  Â· obtain âŸ¨g, h1, n, rflâŸ© := Irreducible.hasSeparableContraction q _ hi
    have h2 : g.natDegree = 1 := by
      rwa [natSepDegree_expand_eq_natSepDegree _ q,

    rw [((monic_expand_iff <| expChar_pow_pos F q n).mp hm).eq_X_add_C h2]
```

I've discovered that `Polynomial.toSubring` is more convenient than `Polynomial.lifts` for this purpose.
```suggestion
  let g : E'[X] := f.toSubring E'.toSubring (subset_adjoin F _)
  have h : g.map (algebraMap E' E) = f := f.map_toSubring E'.toSubring (subset_adjoin F _)
  clear_value g
```

This can be proven using `trans` below; also, mathlib naming convention is `pair` rather than "two".
I have wondered about the result about adjoining an arbitrary set of elements, but then I realized that follows easily once you show the separable elements form a field ... it also follows that sup and iSup of separable intermediate fields are separable.
```suggestion
theorem IntermediateField.isSeparable_adjoin_pair_of_separable {x y : E}
    (hx : (minpoly F x).Separable) (hy : (minpoly F y).Separable) :
    IsSeparable F FâŸ®x, yâŸ¯ := by
  rw [â† adjoin_simple_adjoin_simple]
  replace hy := hy.map.of_dvd (minpoly.dvd_map_of_isScalarTower F FâŸ®xâŸ¯ y)
  rw [â† isSeparable_adjoin_simple_iff_separable] at hx hy
  exact IsSeparable.trans F FâŸ®xâŸ¯ FâŸ®xâŸ¯âŸ®yâŸ¯
```

> I have wondered about the result about adjoining an arbitrary set of elements, but then I realized that follows easily once you show the separable elements form a field ... it also follows that sup and iSup of separable intermediate fields are separable.

Yes, they are [IntermediateField.isSeparable_adjoin_iff_separable](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/c0775a3744e3b5c473405ce86350edc97aaca2a7/Mathlib/FieldTheory/SeparableClosure.lean#L186) and [IntermediateField.isSeparable_iSup](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/c0775a3744e3b5c473405ce86350edc97aaca2a7/Mathlib/FieldTheory/SeparableClosure.lean#L230) in #8696. This `isSeparable_adjoin_two_of_separable` is just an intermediate result used to prove that separable elements form a field.

```suggestion
      rwa [natSepDegree_expand _ q, natSepDegree_eq_natDegree_of_separable g h1] at h
```

If you introduce a lemma
```
theorem natSepDegree_X_pow_char_sub_C (q : â„•) [ExpChar F q] (n : â„•) (y : F) :
    (X ^ q ^ n - C y).natSepDegree = 1 := by
  rw [â† expand_X, â† expand_C (q ^ n), â† map_sub, natSepDegree_expand, natSepDegree_X_sub_C]
```
you can unify both directions of the proof:
```suggestion
theorem natSepDegree_eq_one_iff_mem_pow : (minpoly F x).natSepDegree = 1 â†”
    âˆƒ n : â„•, x ^ q ^ n âˆˆ (algebraMap F E).range := by
  convert_to _ â†” âˆƒ (n : â„•) (y : F), Polynomial.aeval x (X ^ q ^ n - C y) = 0
  Â· simp_rw [RingHom.mem_range, map_sub, map_pow, aeval_C, aeval_X, sub_eq_zero, eq_comm]
  refine âŸ¨fun h â†¦ ?_, fun âŸ¨n, y, hâŸ© â†¦ ?_âŸ©
  Â· obtain âŸ¨n, y, hxâŸ© := (minpoly.natSepDegree_eq_one_iff_eq_X_pow_sub_C q).1 h
    exact âŸ¨n, y, hx â–¸ aeval F xâŸ©
  have hnezero := X_pow_sub_C_ne_zero (expChar_pow_pos F q n) y
  refine ((natSepDegree_le_of_dvd _ _ (minpoly.dvd F x h) hnezero).trans_eq <| 
    natSepDegree_X_pow_char_sub_C q n y).antisymm ?_
  rw [Nat.one_le_iff_ne_zero, natSepDegree_ne_zero_iff, â† Nat.one_le_iff_ne_zero]
  exact minpoly.natDegree_pos <| IsAlgebraic.isIntegral âŸ¨_, hnezero, hâŸ©
```

little golf
```suggestion
    rw [minpoly.aeval, map_sub, map_pow, aeval_X, aeval_C, sub_eq_zero, eq_comm] at hx
    use n
    rw [h, Polynomial.map_sub, Polynomial.map_pow, map_X, map_C, hx, map_pow, â† sub_pow_expChar_pow]
  apply_fun constantCoeff at h
  simp_rw [map_pow, map_sub, constantCoeff_apply, coeff_map, coeff_X_zero, coeff_C_zero] at h
```
I think the `clear_value` is probably unnecessary
same here

(untested) some people might prefer API lemmas over defeq, but I personally think there's no harm exploiting defeq here (same in `separable_add` below) ...
```suggestion
  separable_of_mem_isSeparable F E <| FâŸ®x, yâŸ¯.mul_mem (subset_adjoin F _ (.inl rfl))
    (subset_adjoin F _ (.inr rfl))
```

maybe
```suggestion
- `Field.Emb F E`: the type of `F`-algebra homomorphisms from `E` to the algebraic closure of `E`
  (the algebraic closure of `F` is usually used in the literature, but our definition has the advantage
  that `Field.Emb F E` lies in the same universe as `E` rather than the maximum over `F` and `E`).
```

```suggestion
  `Field.Emb F E` has cardinality `2 ^ Module.rank F (separableClosure F E)`.
```

Side comment: I think the phrase `adjoin_simple` is strange. It's a **simple** extension obtained by **adjoining** a **singleton**. Indeed [similar constructions](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Adjoin/Basic.html#Algebra.self_mem_adjoin_singleton) are called `adjoin_singleton`, but I think we could just use the shorthand `simple` here which also agrees with math terminology. I think we might open a PR to rename all `adjoin_simple` to `simple`.
But `mem_adjoin_simple_self` -> `mem_simple_self` sounds strange ...

(optional) Lean 4 supports the syntax
```suggestion
  let P (K : IntermediateField F E) : Prop := finSepDegree F K = finrank F K
```

```suggestion
  uncountable, while $[\mathbb{Q}(\mu_{p^\infty}):\mathbb{Q}]$ is countable.
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FieldTheory/SeparableDegree): further properties of separable degree of fields and polynomials

nodes.body: From a brief skim up to Line 532:
okay I've now skimmed through the whole PR. Fantastic work! Next time I'll be trying to golf some proofs ...
Is it possible to split the PR? It is currently rather big...
I'm happy with the content, just haven't checked whether some proofs' lengths are justified :)

> Is it possible to split the PR? It is currently rather big...

This PR is already split from #8696. It's possible to further split this into two PRs, one is solely for separable degree of polynomials, another one is the application of these to separable degree of fields. But IMHO this makes PRs too fragmented.

Can you please check the impliciteness of the variables? I've commented some of them, but I have the impression there are several others. Feel free to make a variable explicit even if its type can be inferred if you have a reason to do so, but the opposite should be avoided in my opinion.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8860~~
